title.narrative: Metalens fluorometer to assess drinking water in Nepal

description.narrative: 1. Assemble a handheld fluorometer for the assessment of tryptophan-like fluorescence (TLF) as a proxy for the bacterial contamination of drinking water. The metalens allows a very compact design with high collection efficiency and low dark current detectors. Aim for a similar performance as a commercial fluorometer, equivalent to 1ug/L of tryptophan, but at much lower cost. 2. Design, fabricate and test a chromatic metalens that achieves laterally displaced images for 280 nm and for 350 nm light with minimum (<1%) crosstalk by month 18. 3. Design, fabricate and test thin film metalenses for operation at 280 nm and at 350 nm. Target a numerical aperture >0.7 and a transmission of 50-70% to be achieved in year 1. 4. Engage with end-users such the officials and technicians in the municipality, local NGOs and the public to inform the functionality, design and modus operandi of the instrument, including Nepali software.

The country of Nepal has major issues with the quality of its drinking water. Tools to assess drinking water quality are too expensive and not available. We will address this problem by developing a handheld fluorometer to detect tryptophan-like fluorescence as a proxy for bacterial contamination in drinking water. Our novel design is intrinsically simple and can be made at low cost. The core of the instrument is a high numerical aperture metalens that maximises collection efficiency and that can be made by nanoimprint lithography. The metalens will be designed to be strongly chromatic such that the images for different wavelengths are laterally displaced, such that emitter and detector can be placed next to one another. We will develop a translation pathway for prototype instruments to be made in Nepal for use in local communities.
